title: Tamires Cássia Dias Gomes
text:
Tamires Cássia Dias de Britto (, born 10 October 1987), commonly known as Tamires, is a Brazilian <a href="Association%20football">football</a>er who plays as a left-back for <a href="Sport%20Club%20Corinthians%20Paulista%20%28women%27s%20football%29">Corinthians</a> and the <a href="Brazil%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Brazil national team</a>. She participated at the <a href="2015%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2015</a> and <a href="2019%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2019</a> editions of the <a href="FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">FIFA Women's World Cup</a>, as well as at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2016 Olympic Games</a>.
Club career.
In 2008, Tamires made 10 appearances in the American <a href="USL%20W-League">W-League</a> for <a href="Charlotte%20Lady%20Eagles">Charlotte Lady Eagles</a>, where she was nicknamed "Tam-tam". She joined <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Desportiva%20Centro%20Ol%C3%ADmpico">Centro Olímpico</a> in 2013, after playing for other Brazilian teams including <a href="Santos%20FC%20%28women%29">Santos</a>. In summer 2015 she agreed a move to Danish <a href="Elitedivisionen">Elitedivisionen</a> club <a href="Fortuna%20Hj%C3%B8rring">Fortuna Hjørring</a>.
In June 2019, she agreed a one-year contract with <a href="Sport%20Club%20Corinthians%20Paulista%20%28women%27s%20football%29">Corinthians</a>, who gave her the <a href="Squad%20number%20%28association%20football%29">number</a> 37 <a href="Kit%20%28association%20football%29">shirt</a>.
International career.
Tamires played for the São Paulo select team which represented Brazil at the <a href="2006%20Peace%20Queen%20Cup">2006 Peace Queen Cup</a>. She made her senior debut in September 2013, against <a href="New%20Zealand%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">New Zealand</a> at the <a href="2013%20Valais%20Women%27s%20Cup">2013 Valais Women's Cup</a>. In Brazil's next match she scored her first national team goal in a 4–0 win over <a href="Mexico%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Mexico</a>.
At the <a href="2014%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica%20Femenina">2014 Copa América Femenina</a>, Tamires scored the fifth goal in Brazil's 6–0 rout of <a href="Argentina%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Argentina</a>. In February 2015 she was included in an 18-month residency programme intended to prepare the national team for the <a href="2015%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2015 FIFA Women's World Cup</a> in Canada and the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Rio Olympics</a>. At the 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup, Brazil lost 1–0 in the second round to <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Australia</a>. Tamires remained in Canada as part of the victorious Brazilian selection at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202015%20Pan%20American%20Games%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2015 Pan American Games</a> in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>.
In July 2015 Tamires was the victim of a robbery while leaving her mother's house in <a href="Santo%20Andr%C3%A9%2C%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo">Santo André</a> and her Pan American Games gold medal was stolen. The <a href="Brazilian%20Football%20Confederation">Brazilian Football Confederation</a> (CBF) presented her with a replica.
Tamires was named to the Brazil squad for the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2016 Summer Olympics</a>, her first Olympic Games. She remained the national team's first-choice left-back at the <a href="2019%20FIFA%20Women%27s%20World%20Cup">2019 FIFA Women's World Cup</a> in France. She earned her 100th cap on 12 December 2019 against <a href="Mexico%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Mexico</a>.
Personal life.
Tamires has one son Bernardo together with César Britto
